content.title: Polycythemia Vera
content.summary: Polycythemia vera (PV) is a BCR-ABL-negative myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by clonal proliferation of erythroid, myeloid, and megakaryocytic lineages with predominant erythrocytosis. Over 95% of cases harbor the JAK2 V617F mutation or exon 12 mutations, driving constitutive JAK-STAT signaling and erythropoietin-independent erythropoiesis.
key_points: JAK2 V617F mutation present in >95% of cases; JAK2 exon 12 in remainder
Diagnosis requires elevated hemoglobin/hematocrit plus JAK2 mutation or low EPO with bone marrow findings
Major complications: arterial/venous thrombosis, progression to myelofibrosis or AML
Low-dose aspirin for all patients without contraindications
Cytoreduction (hydroxyurea, interferon-α, ruxolitinib) for high-risk patients
content.statement: Polycythemia vera is a clonal stem cell disorder driven by constitutive JAK2 activation, presenting with erythrocytosis and significant thrombotic risk that is mitigated by maintaining hematocrit below 45% through phlebotomy and risk-adapted cytoreductive therapy.

explanation.intuition: Think of PV as the bone marrow 'gas pedal' being stuck ON - the JAK2 mutation mimics constant EPO signaling, causing uncontrolled red cell production. The thickened blood increases stroke/clot risk, so we drain excess blood (phlebotomy) to thin it out.
explanation.key_insight: The CYTO-PV trial definitively showed hematocrit <45% target reduces thrombosis compared to 45-50%, establishing the current treatment goal. Low-dose aspirin reduces thrombosis without increasing major bleeding in PV.
explanation.technical_details: JAK2 V617F causes constitutive phosphorylation of STAT5, driving EPO-independent erythroid colony formation. Mutant allele burden correlates with disease phenotype. WHO 2016 criteria lowered hemoglobin thresholds (16.5 g/dL men, 16 g/dL women) to improve sensitivity.

definitions_glossary.JAK2_V617F: Acquired somatic mutation in Janus kinase 2 gene causing constitutive kinase activation
definitions_glossary.myeloproliferative_neoplasm: Clonal stem cell disorders with overproduction of mature blood cells
definitions_glossary.erythrocytosis: Increased red blood cell mass; can be primary (PV) or secondary (hypoxia, EPO-producing tumors)
definitions_glossary.phlebotomy: Therapeutic blood removal to reduce hematocrit and blood viscosity
definitions_glossary.hematocrit: Percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells; target <45% in PV
definitions_glossary.erythropoietin: Hormone produced by kidney that stimulates RBC production; suppressed in PV
definitions_glossary.hydroxyurea: Cytoreductive agent that inhibits ribonucleotide reductase; first-line for high-risk PV
definitions_glossary.ruxolitinib: JAK1/JAK2 inhibitor approved for PV resistant/intolerant to hydroxyurea
definitions_glossary.aquagenic_pruritus: Severe itching triggered by water contact; characteristic symptom of PV
definitions_glossary.spent_phase: Late-stage PV with bone marrow fibrosis and cytopenias (post-PV myelofibrosis)
definitions_glossary.thrombosis: Pathologic blood clot formation; major cause of morbidity/mortality in PV
definitions_glossary.hyperviscosity: Increased blood thickness due to elevated hematocrit causing sluggish flow

pathophysiology.mechanism: Constitutive activation of JAK-STAT signaling from JAK2 mutations causing erythropoietin-independent erythroid proliferation

genetic_landscape.JAK2_exon_12: Present in 2-3% of JAK2 V617F-negative PV (isolated erythrocytosis)

disease_evolution.leukemic_transformation: AML (2-5% at 10 years, higher with certain treatments)

major_criteria: Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL (men) or >16 g/dL (women), OR hematocrit >49%/>48%, OR increased red cell mass
Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage proliferation and pleomorphic megakaryocytes
JAK2 V617F or JAK2 exon 12 mutation
WHO_2016_criteria.diagnosis_requirements: All 3 major criteria OR first 2 major + minor criterion

laboratory_findings.CBC: Elevated Hgb/Hct, often elevated WBC and platelets
laboratory_findings.erythropoietin: Low or low-normal (distinguishes from secondary erythrocytosis)
laboratory_findings.iron_studies: May show iron deficiency from repeated phlebotomy
laboratory_findings.uric_acid: Often elevated due to cell turnover

bone_marrow_findings: Absent or minimal reticulin fibrosis in early disease

differential_diagnosis: Secondary erythrocytosis (hypoxia, EPO-producing tumors, exogenous EPO)
Other MPNs with erythrocytosis (primary myelofibrosis, CML)
Congenital polycythemia (EPO receptor mutations, high-affinity hemoglobins)

all_patients.phlebotomy: Target hematocrit <45%; removes ~450 mL per session
all_patients.cardiovascular_risk_reduction: Smoking cessation, BP control, statin therapy

risk_stratification.low_risk: Age <60, no prior thrombosis → phlebotomy + aspirin
risk_stratification.high_risk: Age ≥60 OR prior thrombosis → add cytoreduction

first_line.hydroxyurea: 500-1500 mg daily; teratogenic, theoretical leukemogenic risk
first_line.interferon_alpha: Preferred in younger patients, pregnancy; achieves molecular responses

second_line.ruxolitinib: JAK inhibitor for HU-resistant/intolerant; controls symptoms and splenomegaly

special_situations.pregnancy: High-risk for maternal/fetal complications; use aspirin, phlebotomy, interferon
special_situations.surgery: Normalize hematocrit preoperatively; hold aspirin per protocol

definition.@value: A BCR-ABL-negative myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by clonal erythrocytosis driven by JAK2 mutations, presenting with increased red cell mass, thrombotic risk, and potential for progression to myelofibrosis or acute leukemia

scopeNote.@value: Core MPN concept with defined diagnostic criteria and evidence-based treatment targets

learning_objectives: Apply WHO 2016 diagnostic criteria to diagnose polycythemia vera
Distinguish PV from secondary erythrocytosis using EPO levels and JAK2 testing
Implement phlebotomy to achieve target hematocrit <45%
Risk-stratify patients to determine need for cytoreductive therapy
Recognize clinical features suggesting disease progression
clinical_pearls: JAK2 V617F is present in >95% of PV - if negative, check JAK2 exon 12 mutations
Low EPO level is the key distinguisher from secondary erythrocytosis
CYTO-PV trial: Hct <45% reduces thrombosis 4-fold compared to 45-50%
Aquagenic pruritus (itching after water contact) is highly suggestive of PV
Erythromelalgia (burning pain in hands/feet relieved by aspirin) suggests PV/ET
common_misconceptions: High hemoglobin always means PV - secondary causes are much more common
Phlebotomy alone is sufficient for all PV patients - high-risk patients need cytoreduction
Hydroxyurea causes leukemia - risk is very low and outweighed by thrombosis prevention
